article.name: Smart Groups Reporting Automation Guide
article.title: Smart Groups Reporting Automation Guide
article.body:
In this article, you will learn how to build advanced reporting processes with Smart Groups. We recommend customizing comparative reports to show a variety of statistics, from your users’ phishing failures and training statuses to the overall impact of your security awareness program. This article also explains how to build some other common reporting processes.

For general information about using Smart Groups, see our Smart Groups Quickstart Guide.

Comparative Reporting with Smart Groups

Comparative reports allow you to analyze data from multiple groups in one report. When you create a comparative report with Smart Groups, it will automatically stay up-to-date after you set it up. We recommend scheduling your report to be sent periodically to your organization’s stakeholders so that they regularly receive updated versions of your report.

To learn how to plan and set up a Smart Group, see our Smart Groups Quickstart Guide.

Step One: Create Your Smart Groups

First, create Smart Groups that segment your users by your preferred criteria. We recommend referencing our Smart Groups: Glossary of Criteria Types to find the best criteria types for your Smart Group.

In the examples below, you’ll learn how to build Smart Groups to filter your users by a specific department, division, and location. Click on the tabs below to view our recommended settings for each Smart Group.

Users by Department

Create a Smart Group and name it something identifiable, such as “Reporting Smart Group – [Department Name]”. Add the following User Field criterion to this Smart Group:
  1. User Field: Select Department.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Equal.
  4. Values: Enter the name of the department.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

User Field The department must be equal to [name of department].

Users by Division

Create a Smart Group and name it something identifiable, such as “Reporting Smart Group – [Division Name]”. Add the following User Field criterion to this Smart Group:
  1. User Field: Select Division.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Equal.
  4. Values: Enter the name of the division.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

User Field The division must be equal to [name of division].

Users by Location

Create a Smart Group and name it something identifiable, such as “Reporting Smart Group – [Location Name]”. Add the following User Field criterion to this Smart Group:
  1. User Field: Select Location.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Equal.
  4. Values: Enter your desired location.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

User Field The location must be equal to [desired location].

Step Two: Create Your Report

Now that you’ve created your Smart Groups, add them to a report to review data for those groups. There are a variety of report types available in your KSAT console. For example, a comparative Training Status Overview Report displays the quantity of users in each selected Smart Group who have received, started, or completed their training within a specified period of time.

Once you’ve selected a report type, follow the steps below to set up your comparative report:

  1. In your KSAT console, navigate to the Reports tab.
  2. Select the type of report you want to create.
  3. In the Report Type drop-down menu, select the option ending in “by Group”. For example, the Phish-prone Percentage Report includes the Phish-prone Percentage by Group report type.
  4. In the User Groups drop-down menu, select your reporting Smart Groups.
  5. Click the View Report button to see the results of your report.
  6. Click the Save Report button. Select Generate PDF or Generate CSV to download the information from the report.

Since your report will update over time based on changes to your Smart Groups, we recommend scheduling this report to be sent periodically to stakeholders in your organization. To learn how to schedule and send a report, see our How to Save and Send Reports article.

Risk Reporting with Smart Groups

We recommend using Smart Groups to build a report on the high-risk users in your organization. This report helps you identify areas for improvement in your security awareness program.

Step One: Create Your Risk Reporting Smart Groups

In this section, you’ll learn how to build a variety of risk reporting Smart Groups. Your report can include any combination of these groups. Once you’ve created your Smart Groups, move on to Step Two to learn how to build a report with these groups.

Click on the tabs below to see our recommended settings for each Smart Group:

Untested Users

This Smart Group includes users who have never received a Phishing Security Test (PST). Since these users have not practiced identifying phishing emails, they are more likely to fall for a real phishing attack.

To create this Smart Group, add the following Phish Event criterion:
  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Phish Event: Select Delivered.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Select 0.
  5. Time Frame: Select Any.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Phish Event User must not have received an email more than 0 times.

Users Who Frequently Fail PSTs

This Smart Group includes users who frequently fail PSTs.

This criterion works best if you send PSTs to your users at least monthly. If you test your users less frequently, lower the Count of phishing failures and expand the Time Frame of this criterion.

To create this Smart Group, add the following Phish Event criterion:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Failed Phishing Test.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Select 3.
  5. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 6, and Months.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Phish Event User must have failed a phishing test greater than 3 times in the last 6 months.

High-Risk Users

This Smart Group includes users who have a high risk of failing a PST. This group is filtered by your users’ personal Risk Scores and phishing test failures.

To create this Smart Group, you'll need to add criteria for User Date, Phish Event, and SmartRisk Agent. For more information on these criteria, click the tabs below:
  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Date Type: Select Created.
  3. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 3, and Months.

  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Delivered.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Select 2.
  5. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 6, and Months.

  1. Score Type: Select Risk Score.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Value: Enter your organization’s current Risk Score percentage.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criteria will state:

User Date User must not have been created in the last 3 months.
Phish Event User must have had received an email more than 2 times in the last 6 months.
SmartRisk Agent The Risk Score must be greater than [current organizational Risk Score percentage].

Untrained Users Involved in a Data Breach

This Smart Group includes untrained users who have been involved in a data breach.

Before you create this Smart Group, use our free Email Exposure Check Pro (EEC Pro) tool to search for breached users. When an EEC Pro search finds that a user has been involved in a data breach, this breach event will be automatically added to the user’s User Timeline in your KSAT console.

To create this Smart Group, you'll need to add Breach Event and Training criteria. For more information on these criteria, click the tabs below:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Breach Event: Select Security breach.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Select 1.
  5. Time Frame: Select Any.

  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Training Event: Select Completed.
  3. Scope: Select Any Available.
  4. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criteria will state:

Breach Event User must have been in a security breach more than 1 time.
Training User must not have completed any available courses in the last 12 months.

Untrained Users Who Frequently Fail Phishing Tests

This Smart Group includes untrained users who have failed multiple PSTs. These users may benefit from completing security training.

To create this Smart Group, you'll need to add Training and Phish Event criteria. For more information on these criteria, click the tabs below:
  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Training Event: Select Completed.
  3. Scope: Select Any Available.
  4. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Failed Phishing Test.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Select 1.
  5. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criteria will state:

Training User must not have completed any available courses in the last 12 months.
Phish Event User must have failed a phishing test greater than 1 times in the last 12 months.

Users with a High Phish-prone Percentage

This Smart Group includes users with a high Phish-prone Percentage. We recommend assigning additional security awareness training to this Smart Group.

To create this Smart Group, add the following criterion:
  1. User Field: Select Phish-prone Percentage.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Value: Enter your organization’s average Phish-prone Percentage.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

User Field The Phish-prone Percentage must be greater than [current organizational average].

Users who Failed a Phishing Test After Training

This Smart Group includes users who failed a PST after completing security training. These users may benefit from completing remedial training.

To create this Smart Group, add the following criterion:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Failed Phishing Test.
  3. Training Event: Select Completed.
  4. Assignments: Select the training modules from your organization’s annual training campaign.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

After Training User must have failed a phishing test after completing [annual training assignments].

Untrained Users in High-Risk Roles

This Smart Group includes users who have not completed role-specific security training courses. Before you configure this Smart Group, create a static user group that includes the users in the role you want to target. To learn how to build static groups, see our Users and Groups article.

Once you’ve made your static user group, create a Smart Group with User Field and Training criteria. For more information on these criteria, click the tabs below:
  1. User Field: Select Group Name.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Equal.
  4. Values: Enter the name of the group you’d like to target.

  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Training Event: Select Completed.
  3. Scope: Select All Selected.
  4. Assignments: Select the training modules assigned to this group.
  5. Time Frame: Select Any.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criteria will state:

User Field The group name must be equal to [targeted group].
Training User must not have completed all of these [number] assignments.

Step Two: Create a Risk Report

Once you’ve created your risk reporting Smart Groups, make a report that includes all of these groups. Your risk report shows you how the user count of each Smart Group has changed over time. This report helps you track your organization’s overall security risk level.

Follow the steps below to build your report:

  1. In your KSAT console, navigate to the Reports tab.
  2. Select User Count and Login Reports.
  3. In the Report Type drop-down menu, select User Count.
  4. In the User Groups drop-down menu, select your risk reporting Smart Groups.
  5. In the Date Range drop-down menu, select your target date range.
  6. Click the View Report button to see the results of your report.
  7. Click the Save Report button to save your report. Select Generate PDF or Generate CSV to download the information from the report.

Since your report will update over time based on changes to your Smart Groups, we recommend scheduling this report to be sent periodically to stakeholders in your organization. To learn how to schedule and send a report, see our How to Save and Send Reports article.

Success Reporting with Smart Groups

We recommend using Smart Groups to build a report on your users who have strong security awareness skills. Your success report shows how your security awareness program has impacted your organization over time.

Follow the steps below to create your success report.

Step One: Create Your Success Reporting Smart Groups

This section covers a variety of success reporting Smart Groups. Your report can include any combination of these groups. Once you’ve created your Smart Groups, move on to Step Two to learn how to assign these groups to a report.

Click on the tabs below to see our recommended settings for each Smart Group.

Users Who Frequently Report Phishing Tests

This Smart Group includes users who frequently report PSTs using the Phish Alert Button (PAB).

To create this Smart Group, add the following criterion:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Reported.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Enter your desired number of reported phishing emails.
  5. Time Frame: Select Any.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Phish Event User must have reported a phishing email more than [desired number] times.

Proficient Reporters With No PST Failures

This Smart Group includes users who have never failed a PST and who have reported at least one PST using the PAB.

To create this Smart Group, you'll need to add two Phish Event criteria. For more information on these criteria, click the tabs below:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Reported.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Enter your desired number of reported phishing emails.
  5. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Phish Event: Select Failed Phishing Test.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Enter your desired number of reported phishing emails.
  5. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

After you’ve filled out the criteria listed above, click Save. Your finished criteria will state:

Phish Event User must have reported a phishing email more than [number] times in the last 12 months.
Phish Event User must not have failed a phishing test more than [number] times in the last 12 months.

Currently Tested Users

This Smart Group includes users who have regularly received PSTs over the past 12 months. This group will help you verify that your users are receiving the PSTs you send.

To create this Smart Group, add the following criterion:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Delivered.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Enter your desired number of delivered PSTs. If you send monthly phishing campaigns to your users, enter 11. If you send phishing campaigns less frequently, adjust this number accordingly.
  5. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Phish Event User must have had received an email more than [number] times in the last 12 months.

Users Who Improved After Remedial Training

This Smart Group includes users who failed a PST, completed remedial security training, and did not fail any PSTs after finishing that training. This group tracks the effectiveness of your remedial training campaigns.

To create this Smart Group, add the following criteria:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Phish Event: Select Failed Phishing Test.
  3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
  4. Count: Enter your desired number of failed phishing tests.
  5. Time Frame: Select Range. Then, enter your desired end date in the second date field.

  1. Condition: Select Must Not.
  2. Phish Event: Select Failed Phishing Test.
  3. Training Event: Select Completed.
  4. Assignments: Select the training modules from your organization’s remedial training campaign.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criteria will state:

Phish Event User must have failed a phishing test more than 0 times on or before [desired end date].
After Training User must not have failed a phishing test after completing these [number] assignments.

Currently Trained Users

This Smart Group includes users who have completed training in the last 12 months. If you want to filter users by a different time frame, adjust the Time Frame setting of the criterion.

To create this Smart Group, add the following criterion:
  1. Condition: Select Must.
  2. Training Event: Select Completed.
  3. Scope: Select Any Available.
  4. Time Frame: Select Duration. Then, select In the last, 12, and Months.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Training User must have completed any available courses in the last 12 months.

Step Two: Create a Success Report

Once you’ve created your success reporting Smart Groups, create a report that includes all of these groups. Your success report shows the change in user count of each group over time. This report tracks the effectiveness of your security awareness program.

Follow the steps below to build your report:

  1. In your KSAT console, navigate to the Reports page, then click the Reports tab.
  2. Under the Reports tab, select User Count and Login Reports.
  3. In the Report Type drop-down menu, select User Count.
  4. In the User Groups drop-down menu, select your success reporting Smart Groups.
  5. In the Date Range drop-down menu, select your target date range.
  6. Click the View Report button to see the results of your report.
  7. Click the Save Report button. Select Generate PDF or Generate CSV to download the information from the report.

Since your report will update over time based on changes to your Smart Groups, we recommend scheduling this report to be sent periodically to stakeholders in your organization. To learn how to schedule and send a report, see our How to Save and Send Reports article.

Additional Reporting Processes

Smart Groups help you build a variety of reporting processes. The sections below include examples of common automated reports.

Create a Group Report Card

The Group Report Card displays a group’s Risk Score, training status, and other key metrics. If you assign a Smart Group to the Group Report Card, your report will stay up-to-date over time. We recommend scheduling this report to be sent periodically to stakeholders in your organization.

First, create a Smart Group to filter a specific type of user. This group can be customized to fit your organization’s needs. For example, you could create a Group Report Card for users in your Sales division. To create the Sales Smart Group, add the following criterion:
  1. User Field: Select Division.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Equal.
  4. Values: Enter the name of the group you’d like to target.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

User Field The division must be equal to [name of targeted group].

Then, use the steps below to assign the Smart Group to a Group Report Card:

  1. In your KSAT console, navigate to the Reports tab.
  2. Select Group and User Report Cards.
  3. Under the Report Type drop-down menu, select Group Report Card.
  4. Under the Group drop-down menu, select your Sales Smart Group.
  5. Select a Date Range that fits your organization’s needs.
  6. Click the Save Report button. To download the report, select Generate PDF.

Repeat the process above to create additional Smart Group report cards.

Create Manager Reporting for Specific Divisions

Manager reporting allows you to create reports about a certain manager’s team or a specific division in your organization. Then, you can share these reports with the relevant manager.

Before you create this Smart Group, verify that the Manager Email field is up-to-date in the Users tab of your KSAT console.

Then, add manager usernames to sort your users by their manager. We recommend customizing these usernames to fit your organization’s reporting hierarchy. For example, users who report to a manager named Smith could have the username ManagerSmith. Add the usernames to Custom Field 1 in the Users tab of your KSAT console.

Once you’ve added your manager email addresses and usernames, create a Smart Group for each manager. Add the following criterion to each group:
  1. User Field: Select Custom Field 1.
  2. Condition: Select Must.
  3. Comparison: Select Ends With.
  4. Values: Enter the username of the manager whose team you want to create a report for.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

User Field The Custom Field 1 must end with [desired manager username].

After you create your manager Smart Groups, assign them to a report that fits your organization’s needs. Then, send the report to each manager. To learn how to share a report, see our How to Save and Send Reports article.

Provide Managers Custom Reporting Access for Their Team

If your organization requires access to custom reports, our Security Roles feature allows you to give managers access to view Smart Groups in your KSAT console. With this access, managers can review data on specific groups of users, such as their direct reports. For example, you could create a Smart Group of users under a certain manager who have failed multiple phishing security tests (PSTs).

The manager can view this Smart Group and communicate with their team as needed.

First, add your organization’s managers to a static user group. We recommend using our CSV Import or Quick Import features to quickly group your managers in your KSAT console.

Next, create a Security Role for your static group of managers. To set up this Security Role, follow the steps below:

  1. Navigate to the Users page, then click the Security Roles tab.
  2. Click the New Security Role button in the top-right of the screen.
  3. In the Groups drop-down menu, select your static user group.
  4. Under the General tab of the security role, select Read permissions for Users & Groups.
  5. In the Targeted Groups drop-down menu, select the Smart Groups that you would like your managers to access.
  6. Click the Create Security Role button.

images.alt:
This image displays a **user interface form panel** for defining a conditional rule, likely a filter or access control setting.

**UI Elements and Structure:**

The panel contains four labeled sections, each featuring a dropdown or input field:

1.  **User Field:** Label defines the attribute being filtered. The corresponding input is a dropdown menu currently displaying the value **"Department"**.
2.  **Condition:** Label defines the logical requirement of the rule. The corresponding input is a dropdown menu currently displaying the value **"Must"**.
3.  **Comparison:** Label defines the operator for the comparison. The corresponding input is a dropdown menu currently displaying the value **"Equal"**.
4.  **Values:** Label defines the target data for comparison. The corresponding input field displays the text **"Department Name"**. This input also includes an 'X' icon (for removal) and a dropdown arrow, suggesting it is a dynamic tag or selectable value input.

**Action Buttons:**

At the bottom of the panel, two action buttons are present:

*   **Cancel:** A gray, inactive-style button.
*   **Save:** A blue, active-style button.

**Context:**

The structure indicates the creation of a rule that evaluates to: "User Field (Department) **Must** be **Equal** to Value (Department Name)." The numerical labels (1 through 4 in orange circles) are annotations for documentation and not part of the standard UI.

This image displays a configuration form used for defining a specific rule or filter criteria.

**UI Elements and Configuration:**

1.  **User Field:** Labeled "User Field," configured with a dropdown displaying the selected value "**Division**."
2.  **Condition:** Labeled "Condition," configured with a dropdown displaying the selected value "**Must**."
3.  **Comparison:** Labeled "Comparison," configured with a dropdown displaying the selected value "**Equal**."
4.  **Values:** Labeled "Values," configured with an input field displaying the text "**Division Name**." This input field includes an 'X' symbol for removal and a dropdown arrow for modification.

**Action Buttons:**

At the bottom of the form, two action buttons are present:
*   **Cancel:** A gray, inactive-style button.
*   **Save:** A blue, active-style button.

The overall context suggests setting a constraint or requirement where the user attribute "Division" must be "Equal" to a specified value, currently identified as "Division Name."

This image displays a User Interface (UI) module for defining a specific filtering rule or condition, organized into four primary labeled fields, each utilizing a selection component.

**Configuration Elements (Top-Down):**

1.  **User Field:** Label identifying the field to be filtered. The current selection is **Location**. (Input is a dropdown menu).
2.  **Condition:** Label specifying the logical requirement of the rule. The current selection is **Must**. (Input is a dropdown menu).
3.  **Comparison:** Label defining the relationship operator. The current selection is **Equal**. (Input is a dropdown menu).
4.  **Values:** Label for the data against which the comparison is executed. The input field displays the selected value **Location Name** and features both a removal icon (X) and a nested dropdown arrow, suggesting multi-value input or tag-based selection.

**Action Controls:**

At the bottom of the module, two controls are present:

*   A secondary, gray button labeled **Cancel**.
*   A primary, highlighted blue button labeled **Save**.

This is a detailed description of the Reporting screen, focusing on the "Training Status Overview Reports" interface and data display.

**1. Header and Navigation:**
*   The primary title is **"Reporting"**.
*   A contextual link is present in the top right: **"← Back to All Reports"**.
*   The sub-navigation bar includes four tabs: **Reports** (active), **Saved Reports**, **Scheduled Reports**, and **Download Center**.

**2. Report Configuration Filters:**
*   The subsection is titled **"Training Status Overview Reports"** (includes a tooltip icon).
*   Three dropdown selectors define the report parameters:
    *   **Report Type:** Set to "Training Status Overview by User Group".
    *   **User Groups:** Set to "3 Groups Selected".
    *   **Date Range:** Set to "Last 6 Months".
*   An action button, **"Save Report"**, is located to the right of the filters.

**3. Graphical Data Display (Stacked Bar Chart):**
*   The chart is titled **"Training Status Overview By Group"**.
*   The accompanying descriptive text reads: "This report displays the total number of users by group in each training status, for all campaigns."
*   A legend identifies the status colors: **Not Started** (Light Blue), **In Progress** (Dark Gray/Black), and **Completed** (Light Green).
*   The X-axis displays three groups: IT, Accounting, and Sales.
*   Data visualization (stacked bars, values annotated within the segments):
    *   **IT:** Completed (22), In Progress (1), Not Started (87).
    *   **Accounting:** Completed (592), In Progress (1), Not Started (17).
    *   **Sales:** Completed (75), In Progress (5), Not Started (508).

**4. Tabular Data Display:**
*   A data table presents the numerical breakdown, confirming the stacked bar chart data.
*   Columns are sortable (indicated by directional arrows): **Group Name**, **Completed**, **In Progress**, and **Not Started**.

| Group Name | Completed | In Progress | Not Started |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| IT | 22 | 1 | 17 |
| Accounting | 592 | 1 | 17 |
| Sales | 75 | 5 | 508 |

**5. Export Options and Footer:**
*   A collapsible link is available: **"Report Details ►"**.
*   Two export hyperlinks are present at the bottom of the data section: **"Generate PDF"** and **"Generate CSV"**.
*   The page footer contains standard navigation links (About, Privacy Policy, Need Help?) and a copyright notice: "© 2022 KnowBe4, Inc. All rights reserved".
images.context: e received, started, or completed their training within a specified period of time.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration form or rule builder, likely for filtering or defining conditions related to security or event logging. The interface consists of five primary input fields and two action buttons.

**UI Elements and Values:**

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown menu currently set to the value **"Must Not"**.
2.  **Phish Event:** A dropdown menu currently displaying the value **"Delivered"**.
3.  **Comparison:** A dropdown menu currently set to the value **"Greater Than"**.
4.  **Count:** A numeric input field with a current value of **"0"**. This field is flanked by stepper controls: a decrement button (labeled **"-"**) on the left and an increment button (labeled **"+"**) on the right.
5.  **Time Frame:** A segmented control selector with three options. The current selection is **"Any"** (dark gray background), followed by unselected options **"Range"** and **"Duration"** (white backgrounds).

**Action Controls:**

Located at the bottom of the visible area are two standard action buttons:
*   **Cancel** (Secondary action, dark gray).
*   **Save** (Primary action, blue).

The image displays a user interface configuration panel, likely for setting a rule or filter criterion, organized into five primary sections.

1.  **Condition:** Dropdown menu set to the value "Must."
2.  **Phish Event:** Dropdown menu set to the value "Failed Phishing Test."
3.  **Comparison:** Dropdown menu set to the value "Greater Than."
4.  **Count:** Numerical input field displaying the value "3," bordered by decrement (-) and increment (+) buttons.
5.  **Time Frame:** This section utilizes a segmented control with three options: "Range," "**Duration**" (selected/active), and "Any." Nested inputs, controlled by the active "Duration" selection, are configured as follows:
    *   Dropdown menu set to "In the last."
    *   Numerical input field set to the value "6."
    *   Dropdown menu specifying units set to "Months."

The panel concludes with two action buttons: a standard button labeled "**Cancel**" and a primary button labeled "**Save**."

This image displays a UI panel or dialog box for defining a date-based filter, featuring three main sections labeled **1**, **2**, and **3**.

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown field currently set to **Must Not**.
2.  **Date Type:** A dropdown field currently set to **Created**.
3.  **Time Frame:** A selector with three mutually exclusive options presented as tabs: **Range**, **Duration** (active, dark gray background), and **Any**.

Below the active "Duration" selection, additional configuration fields appear:

*   A dropdown field labeled **In the last** (implied context, showing the selected value).
*   A numerical input field with a displayed value of **3**. This field is flanked by a decrement button (**-**) on the left and an increment button (**+**) on the right.
*   A dropdown field showing the unit of time, currently set to **Months**.

The panel concludes with two action buttons at the bottom: **Cancel** (gray background) and **Save** (blue background).

The image displays a user interface panel for configuring a threshold rule based on "Phish Event" metrics. The configuration utilizes sequential labeled fields, predominantly dropdown menus and numerical inputs.

### UI Element Breakdown:

1.  **Condition:** Dropdown menu set to **Must**.
2.  **Phish Event:** Dropdown menu set to **Delivered**.
3.  **Comparison:** Dropdown menu set to **Greater Than**.
4.  **Count:** Numerical input field currently set to **2**. The input field is bounded by standard decrement (-) and increment (+) controls.
5.  **Time Frame:** This section controls the scope of the count and features a segmented control for selection:
    *   **Segmented Control:** Options include "Range," "**Duration**" (currently selected, highlighted in dark gray), and "Any."
    *   **Duration Configuration (Active):**
        *   Dropdown Menu 1: Set to **In the last**.
        *   Numerical Input: Set to **6**, bounded by decrement (-) and increment (+) controls.
        *   Dropdown Menu 2: Set to **Months**.

### Action Controls (Footer):

The form concludes with two action buttons positioned at the bottom left:
*   **Cancel** (Standard button, dark gray fill).
*   **Save** (Primary action button, blue fill).

This image displays a configuration form used for defining a specific rule or condition, potentially for filtering or security access. The form contains four numbered sections (labeled 1 through 4 in orange circles) consisting of labels and input fields.

2.  **Condition:**
    *   **Label:** Condition

3.  **Comparison:**
    *   **Label:** Comparison
    *   **Input Type:** Dropdown/Select box
    *   **Current Value:** Equal
    *   **Purpose:** Specifies the operator for the evaluation (e.g., Equal, Not Equal, Contains).

4.  **Values:**
    *   **Label:** Values
    *   **Input Type:** Tag/Value input field
    *   **Current Value:** Accounting (displayed as a single, removable tag, indicated by an 'x' icon next to the text). A separate dropdown arrow suggests the ability to add more values or choose from a list.

**Action Buttons:**

At the bottom of the form, two standard action buttons are presented:

*   **Cancel:** A gray, subdued button.
*   **Save:** A blue, primary action button.

This image displays a configuration panel for defining criteria, likely for a rule or filter related to user training compliance.

The panel consists of five main labeled sections, each containing input fields:

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown menu is set to **"Must Not"**.
2.  **Training Event:** A dropdown menu is set to **"Completed"**.
3.  **Scope:** A dropdown menu is set to **"All Selected"**.
4.  **Assignments:** A multi-select input field displays three selected training titles formatted as removable tags (with an 'X' icon):
    *   "2023 Kevin Mitnick Security Awareness Training - 1..."
    *   "2023 Your Role: Internet Security and You"
    *   "Captain Awareness: Be a Human Firewall"
5.  **Time Frame:** This section features a segmented control with three options, where the third option is selected and darkened:
    *   **Range** (Unselected)
    *   **Duration** (Unselected)
    *   **Any** (Selected)

At the bottom of the panel are two action buttons: **"Cancel"** (gray) and **"Save"** (blue, indicating the primary action).

The image displays a software interface for generating **User Count and Login Reports**.

### I. Report Controls (Header)

The top section provides report filtering controls:
1.  **Report:** Dropdown set to "User Count".
2.  **User Groups:** Dropdown indicating "8 items selected...".
3.  **Date Range:** Dropdown set to "Entire History".
4.  **Action Button:** A blue button labeled "View Report".

### II. Data Visualization (User Counts Chart)

A line chart titled "User Counts" visualizes data over time (April 2018 to January 2021).
*   **Y-Axis:** Labeled "User Count", scaled from 0 to 2,500.
*   **X-Axis:** Temporal scale showing quarterly intervals.
*   **Primary Data Trend:** The purple line (`!MS Reporting – General – All User Count`) shows overall growth, starting at low numbers and reaching 2,055 users by January 2021.
*   **Secondary Data Trends:** Multiple other user groups are tracked, showing counts ranging from 12 (for the Untested group) up to 701 (for the High Risk group) by the end of the period.

### III. Legend and Contextual Information

The report includes a detailed legend listing eight groups tracked:
*   **!MS Reporting – General – All User Count** (Purple Line)
*   **!MS Reporting- Risk- High Risk** (Blue Line/Dot)
*   **!MS Reporting – Risk – Untrained Clickers** (Green Line/Star)
*   **!MS Reporting- Risk- Untested** (Dark Blue Line/Diamond)
*   **!MS Reporting – Risk – High Phish-Prone** (Yellow Line/Triangle)
*   **!MS Reporting- Risk- Habitual Clickers** (Dark Purple Line/Square)
*   **!MS Reporting – Risk – Untrained Breached Users** (Cyan Line/Circle)
*   **!MS Reporting – Risk – Failed After Training** (Red Line/Triangle)

Below the chart, a descriptive section titled "User Counts" explains the report purpose: "This report displays the number of all active users in the selected user groups, during the specified date range." It also notes: "Groups without relevant data will not appear on this report."

The final section explicitly lists the eight groups included in the report calculation.
images.context: report helps you track your organization’s overall security risk level.

images.alt:
The image displays a user interface segment for configuring a rule, organized into five primary input fields followed by action buttons.

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown menu displaying the selection **Must**.
2.  **Phish Event:** A dropdown menu displaying the selection **Reported**.
3.  **Comparison:** A dropdown menu displaying the selection **Greater Than**.
4.  **Count:** A numerical input field featuring decrement (-) and increment (+) buttons. The current value displayed is **3**.
5.  **Time Frame:** A segmented control selector with three options: **Range**, **Duration**, and **Any**. The **Any** option is currently selected (highlighted in dark gray).

At the bottom of the interface, two action buttons are present: a secondary button labeled **Cancel** (gray) and a primary button labeled **Save** (blue).

This image displays a configuration form for defining a conditional rule, likely related to security event filtering. The interface is composed of vertically stacked labeled input fields and ends with action buttons.

**UI Elements and Configuration:**

1.  **Condition:** Dropdown menu displaying the selected value: **Must**.
2.  **Phish Event:** Dropdown menu displaying the selected value: **Reported**.
3.  **Comparison:** Dropdown menu displaying the selected value: **Greater Than**.
4.  **Count:** Numeric stepper input field displaying the value **0**. This field is bracketed by decrement (–) and increment (+) controls.
5.  **Time Frame:** This section utilizes a segmented control offering three choices: **Range**, **Duration** (selected, indicated by dark gray background), and **Any**.

    *   Below the segmented control, three related inputs define the duration:
        *   Dropdown menu displaying **In the last**.
        *   Numeric stepper input field displaying the value **12**.
        *   Dropdown menu displaying the time unit **Months**.

**Action Buttons:**

At the bottom of the interface, two action buttons are present: **Cancel** (gray background) and **Save** (blue background).

This image displays a User Interface (UI) form used for defining an event-based rule or filter criterion, likely within a security or compliance management system.

The form contains five primary configuration fields:

1.  **Condition:** Configured via a dropdown menu, currently set to **Must Not**.
2.  **Phish Event:** Configured via a dropdown menu, currently set to **Failed Phishing Test**.
3.  **Comparison:** Configured via a dropdown menu, currently set to **Greater Than**.
4.  **Count:** Configured via a numeric input field with dedicated increment/decrement buttons (- / +). The current value is **0**.
5.  **Time Frame:** Defined using a three-option segmented control (Range, **Duration**, Any).

    *   **Duration** is currently selected (highlighted in dark gray).
    *   The duration parameters are set using a cascading structure:
        *   The first dropdown displays the phrase **In the last**.
        *   The time quantity is set to **12** using a numeric input field with increment/decrement controls.
        *   The time unit is selected via a dropdown menu, currently set to **Months**.

The bottom of the UI features two action buttons: **Cancel** (unaccented gray) and **Save** (accented blue).

The configuration defines a rule requiring that the specified entity **Must Not** have recorded a **Failed Phishing Test** **Greater Than 0** times within the last **12 Months**.

This image displays a configuration panel for defining a complex filter or condition, likely within a security or analytics platform focused on phishing events.

The UI consists of five primary labeled sections, each utilizing either a dropdown menu or input fields:

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown menu currently set to **Must**.
2.  **Phish Event:** A dropdown menu currently set to **Delivered**.
3.  **Comparison:** A dropdown menu currently set to **Greater Than**.
4.  **Count:** A numerical input field, functioning as a stepper control (with **-** and **+** buttons), currently set to **11**.
    *   *Implied Rule:* The current configuration defines a filter where the count of 'Delivered' events must be 'Greater Than 11'.
5.  **Time Frame:** This section uses a segmented control with three options: **Range**, **Duration** (active, dark gray background), and **Any**. Since **Duration** is active, three dependent fields are displayed below:
    *   A dropdown menu starting with the text **In the last**.
    *   A numerical stepper input field set to **12**.
    *   A dropdown menu defining the unit, currently set to **Months**.
    *   *Implied Rule:* The filter applies to events occurring 'In the last 12 Months'.

At the bottom of the panel are two action buttons: **Cancel** (gray, standard button) and **Save** (blue, primary action button).

This image displays a configuration panel used to define a security or policy rule based on phishing test results. The panel includes five primary input fields and a concluding action bar.

**UI Elements and Configuration Details:**

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown menu set to the value **Must**.
2.  **Phish Event:** A dropdown menu set to the value **Failed Phishing Test**.
3.  **Comparison:** A dropdown menu set to the value **Greater Than**.
4.  **Count:** A number input field, bordered by decrement (`-`) and increment (`+`) buttons, set to the value **0**.
5.  **Time Frame:** A segmented control with three options: **Range** (selected), **Duration**, and **Any**.
    *   Since **Range** is selected, two calendar/date input fields are displayed:
        *   The Start Date field is empty, preceded by a calendar icon.
        *   The label **Through** is displayed, followed by a help icon (`?`).
        *   The End Date field is displayed with a calendar icon and the pre-filled date **09/08/2023**.

**Action Controls:**
The bottom of the panel contains two buttons:
*   **Cancel** (Gray button, secondary action).
*   **Save** (Blue button, primary action).

The image displays a user interface configuration panel, likely for setting up security training rules or conditions. The panel consists of four labeled input fields, followed by contextual text and action buttons.

**UI Components and Settings:**

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown input field set to the value **"Must Not"**.
2.  **Phish Event:** A dropdown input field set to the value **"Failed Phishing Test"**.
3.  **Training Event:** A dropdown input field set to the value **"Completed"**.
4.  **Assignments:** A multi-select input field (displayed as tags/chips) listing three specific training courses:
    *   "2023 Your Role: Internet Security and You"
    *   "Captain Awareness: Be a Human Firewall"

*   Below the Assignments field, the logic definition **"Matches on all selected options."** is displayed.

**Action Buttons:**

The image displays a configuration panel, likely for a rule, filter, or requirement definition, focusing on four primary criteria fields.

**Criteria Fields (Top to Bottom):**

1.  **Condition:** A dropdown input with the current value set to **Must**.
2.  **Training Event:** A dropdown input with the current value set to **Completed**.
3.  **Scope:** A dropdown input with the current value set to **Any Available**.

**Time Frame Configuration (Section 4):**

This section uses a segmented control for selecting the type of time constraint, followed by conditional fields:

*   **Segmented Control:** Features three toggle options: `Range`, `Duration`, and `Any`. The **Duration** option is selected (highlighted in dark gray with white text).
*   **Duration Settings (Visible):**
    *   Dropdown 1: Set to **In the last**.
    *   Numeric Input/Spinner: Displays the value **12**, flanked by decrement (`-`) and increment (`+`) controls.
    *   Dropdown 2: Set to **Months**.

**Action Buttons:**

The panel concludes with two action buttons located at the bottom:

*   **Cancel** (Secondary button, dark gray).
*   **Save** (Primary button, blue accent).

This screen captures a dynamic reporting interface titled **"User Count and Login Reports"** (accompanied by a help icon).

The interface is divided into two primary sections: Report Configuration and Report Output.

### 1. Report Configuration (Filter Panel)

Three key parameters are defined via dropdown selectors:
*   **Report:** Set to "User Count."
*   **User Groups:** Indicates **"6 items selected..."**
*   **Date Range:** Set to **"Entire History."**

An active action button, labeled **"View Report,"** is present beneath the selectors.

### 2. Report Output (Data Visualization)

The output is headlined **"User Counts"** and displays a multi-line time-series chart:

*   **Y-Axis:** Labeled "User Count," scaled incrementally up to 2500.
*   **X-Axis:** Displays time intervals ranging from April 2018 through January 2021.
*   **Data:** Six distinct, labeled data series are plotted, tracking cumulative user counts over time. Numerical labels show the exact count for each major interval.

**Legend and Footnotes:**

The report includes a legend identifying the six user groups, such as "IMS Reporting - General - All User Count," "IMS Reporting - Successes - Reported & No Failures," and "IMS Reporting - Successes - Currently Trained."

The context section below the chart provides descriptive text:
*   **Purpose:** "This report displays the number of all active users in the selected user groups, during the specified date range."
*   **Note:** "Groups without relevant data will not appear on this report."
*   **Selected Groups:** A detailed, concatenated list of the six user groups included in the visualized data is provided.
images.context: This report tracks the effectiveness of your security awareness program.

images.alt:
This image displays a UI panel for defining a filtering rule, likely within an administration or configuration screen. The panel uses four primary input fields, followed by action buttons.

**UI Elements and Content:**

1.  **User Field:** Labeled "User Field," this dropdown is set to the value **"Division."** (Dropdown control indicated by a double-arrow icon).
2.  **Condition:** Labeled "Condition," this dropdown is set to **"Must."** (Dropdown control).
3.  **Comparison:** Labeled "Comparison," this dropdown is set to **"Equal."** (Dropdown control).
4.  **Values:** Labeled "Values," this input field or multi-select component contains the entry **"Sales."** This field includes an 'X' icon for removal and a dropdown arrow.

**Action Buttons:**

At the bottom of the configuration panel are two standard action buttons:
*   **Cancel** (Neutral gray background).
*   **Save** (Primary blue background).

The overall context suggests the creation or editing of a constraint or access rule, specifying that a user's "Division" field "Must" be "Equal" to the value "Sales."

The image displays a user interface for configuring a specific filtering or matching rule, structured into four labeled sections followed by action buttons.

**Rule Configuration Fields:**

1.  **User Field:** A dropdown selector with the current value set to **"Custom Field 1."**
2.  **Condition:** A dropdown selector with the current value set to **"Must."**
3.  **Comparison:** A dropdown selector with the current value set to **"Ends With."**
4.  **Values:** An input field containing the text **"JohnSmith."** This input field includes a clear/dismiss icon ('x') and a secondary dropdown menu.

**Action Controls:**

The interface concludes with two action buttons positioned below the configuration fields:
*   **Cancel:** A gray, secondary action button.
*   **Save:** A blue, primary action button.
